title: Restored Jacobean Manor Selling For Second Time in 400 Years
text:
A once-derelict Jacobean manor house in South West England has come back up for sale after a 10-year restoration—including the addition of an award-winning gin distillery and a working speakeasy.



Newton House, a nine-bedroom stone mansion in Yeovil, Somerset, hit the market late last month asking £5.95 million (US$7.71 million)—only the second time in 400 years that the grand estate has been available for sale, according to the property agents at Knight Frank.



More: For Foreign House Hunters in London, the Time to Act Is Now

It’s hard to overstate the degree to which Newton House and its historic gardens have transformed since the estate last traded hands in 2007.



That was the year Robin and Jane Cannon purchased the dilapidated manor house and its 62 surrounding acres—which were, in their own words, “in a very sorry state of decay.”



Since then, “every square inch of the house and outbuildings and every square yard of the grounds have been lovingly restored,” the Cannons write on a website for award-winning Newton House Gin, which they now distill on the property.



The main house, which had not been properly lived in for decades, was a time capsule for centuries past. There were ancient tapestries, intricately carved wood paneling and Victorian architectural quirks, such as a primitive lavatory from the time, The Times of London reported when the home was last listed in 2007.



In 2008, a stockpile of nearly 400 valuable antiques and Oriental carpets from the estate were auctioned by Sotheby’s in London to the tune of £2.24 million.



Meanwhile, the Cannons were busy bringing the ramshackle mansion, which reportedly lacked everything from basic heating to a functional roof, into the 21st century.



“The owners have spent years sympathetically restoring the house and improving the internal rooms and configuration,” according to the listing agency. Those include opening up a new entrance to the home’s interior courtyard for better flow and enlarging the family kitchen and dining area, which adjoin a preserved “museum kitchen.”



There’s also a new bar, a home cinema and a master suite with two attached dressing rooms and an en-suite bathroom. Outside, the sellers built two large showroom garages with space for 12 vehicles, according to Knight Frank.



Still, images show the Grade I-listed building has retained many period finishes, including its voluminous, oak-paneled living rooms on the ground level that include ornate stone fireplaces and detailed ceiling plasterwork.

Numerous outbuildings, including the stable block, coach house and various store houses, allowed the owners to embark on a parallel project as they restored Newton House: a small-batch gin distillery using herbs and botanicals from restored gardens and natural spring water running through the estate.



In 2017, the owners converted the stables and coach house, into a venue called The Bespoke Gin House, where they host regular gin and jazz evenings, according to their website. The owners could not immediately be reached for comment.



The distillery is also available for sale by separate negotiation, according to the agency.
